I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Viet  Nam  formally  joined  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  in  January  2007. 
Subsequently,  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  developed  an  “After  WTO”  Action  Plan  for  high 
economic  growth  and  sustainable  development.  The  action  plan  includes  preparation  for 
implementation of WTO commitments and identifies domestic reforms to increase the benefits from 
WTO accession. The Ministry of  Finance (MOF) developed its action plan with the following 
objectives  i)  ensuring  compliance  with  commitments  made  under  WTO,  the  Association  of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free Trade Area, and other preferential trade arrangements 
(PTAs) with individual trading partners; and ii) strengthening capacity within MOF to formulate 
policies to address challenges arising from increased international integration. The MOF’s priorities 
focus on addressing the effects greater international integration on state budget revenues and 
economy-wide  impacts.  The  Government  requested  that  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
provide advisory technical assistance (TA) to support selected components of the MOF’s action 
plan. The TA follows on from small-scale TA provided to MOF in 2004 to support preparations for 
WTO accession. ADB fielded a fact-finding mission in November 2007 to discuss and reach an 
understanding with the Government about the objectives and scope of the proposed TA1, the terms 
of reference for consultants, and the cost and implementation arrangements. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND ISSUES 
2.  Viet Nam’s WTO Commitments. Viet Nam has agreed that the majority of agricultural and 
non-agricultural goods can be imported with duties ranging from 0 to 35% (known as bound rates). 
Duties on some products will be reduced in a phased manner until 2014. The bound rates are legal 
ceilings: Viet Nam can decide to apply lower rates. Products with higher ceilings include alcoholic 
drinks, tobacco products, instant coffee, new and used motor vehicles and components, and roof 
tiles. Viet Nam has also agreed to comply with WTO rules on customs valuation, rules of origin, 
pre-shipment  inspection,  anti-dumping,  safeguards,  subsidies,  and  trade-related  investment 
measures, but some of these provisions have a transition period. Tariff rate quotas2 are in place for 
a limited number of agriculture products, and Viet Nam has agreed to gradually raise the quotas 
until they disappear according to agreed timetables. As part of its accession conditions, Viet Nam 
has been classified as having non-market status, which permits trading partners to apply less 
stringent criteria for determining anti-dumping claims against Viet Nam’s exports.  
 
3.  Implementing Viet Nam’s tariff binding commitments will reduce the average and 
dispersion  of  tariffs  (from  17.5%  currently  to  13.6%  by  2014).  This  reform  will  improve 
incentives for investment and resource utilization. However, compared with some countries, Viet 
Nam does not seem to have taken the opportunity of accession to lock in a tariff regime more 
suitable for an open trading economy. Some bound rates are higher than current applied rates, and 
more than 50% of bindings are at rates of 20% or higher. The pattern of bindings seems to reflect a 
fairly typical trade negotiator’s approach to tariff setting: most of the big cuts implied by the 
bindings seem to be in areas where the tariff is largely redundant—i.e., where Viet Nam is a 
successful exporter or where competition from imports is limited. The tariff cuts will reduce effective 
protection across the traded goods element of the economy, but pockets of high protection will be 
allowed to persist if Viet Nam maintains rates at bound levels. This outcome has arisen partly 
because the Government has not developed procedures to ensure that it is taking a "whole of 
government" approach to tariff policy formulation.3 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 7 December 2007. 
2  Tariff rate quotas refer to import items that are subject to tariff rates on quantities exceeding the quota. 
3  The “whole of government’’ approach takes in account producers and consumers into consideration when formulating 
policies.

2   
4.  The tariff cuts that will follow from implementation of bindings look set to reduce 
tariff revenues. Figure 1 provides three possible scenarios for the treatment of binding tariffs 
under WTO accession. The base case assumes "most favored nation" tariff rates and exemptions 
fixed  at  2005  levels  (pre-WTO  accession).  Scenarios  2  to  4  make  assumptions  about  the 
implementation  of  binding  tariff  rates  and  treatment  of  exemptions.  As  can  be  seen, 
implementation of binding rates will lead to reduced tariff revenues, and only in scenario 4 will tariff 
revenues recover to the pre-WTO trajectory, and this will take until 2018 or 2019. The Government 
also  intends  to  negotiate  future  PTAs  with  the  Republic  of  Korea,  Japan,  and  possibly  the 
European Union, and these arrangements will further lower tariff revenues and impact resource 
mobilization within the domestic economy. 
 
5.  Enhancing  tax  revenue  collections. Several countries have recovered lost trade tax 
revenue by enhancing domestic revenue collection. Their experience suggests that: (i) revenue 
recovery requires a committed effort to broaden tax bases by purging exemptions, simplifying the 
tax  structure,  and  improving  tax  administration;  (ii)  the  domestic  consumption  tax  system,  in 
particular the value-added tax (VAT) and excises taxes, play a crucial role; (iii) income taxes can 
also make an important contribution; and (iv) trade liberalization needs to be closely sequenced 
with domestic tax reform. Scenario 4 indicates that a large part of this revenue loss could be made 
up  by  reducing  concessions  and  exemptions  and  improving  the  efficiency  of  customs 
administration.  Shortfalls  could  also  be  made  up  by  adopting  a  different  approach  to  taxing 
petroleum products. More importantly, any assessment of the revenue effects needs to be carried 
out in a way that takes account of the broader range of changes affecting the revenue and 
expenditure  system.  For  example,  economic  growth  should  expand  the  revenue  base,  and 
reductions in subsidies will reduce expenditures of subsidized commodities.

6.  The Government has developed an action plan to address revenue shortfalls arising 
from WTO accession. MOF recognizes that several major taxes need to be updated to reflect 
changes in the structure of the economy and national government budget, as well as changes in 
development  objectives.  The  Government  also  recognizes  that  the  new  challenges  to  its

3
competitiveness arising from improved market access will require reforms to key domestic policies, 
including tax policy and administration. In this context, MOF anticipates submitting to the National 
Assembly in May or June 2008 amendments to the laws on VAT and the corporate income tax. It 
also anticipates submitting to the National Assembly amendments to laws on excise taxes, land 
and property taxes, and an environmental tax at the end of 2008 or 2009. MOF also recognizes 
that remaining subsidies (e.g., investment incentives and land-use fees) affect both the national 
budget and economic efficiency, and need to be reexamined. 
 
7.  The Ministry of Finance’s action plan has also identified a need to build capacity in 
tax and trade policy formulation. In line with best international practices, MOF separated tax 
policy formulation from tax administration in 2004. The Department of Tax Policy was established 
and  charged  with  analyzing  taxes  and  formulating  tax  policy.  MOF  is  also  responsible  for 
formulating tariff policy in coordination with key line ministries, including the Ministry of Trade and 
Industry, Ministry of Agriculture, and Ministry of Planning and Investment. One lesson from Viet 
Nam's WTO accession experience is the importance of developing a consultative process for trade 
policy formulation that takes a "whole of government" approach. Viet Nam intends to negotiate 
additional PTAs with key trading partners and it will be important that the Government carries out 
economy-wide assessment of the proposed PTAs to ensure that they provide net benefits to Viet 
Nam. In June 2006, MOF set up the Policy Advisory Group to provide independent and timely 
economic policy advice to MOF on a wide range of economic policy issues, including taxes and 
trade, and to assist with strengthening MOF's policy capacity. In this regard, MOF considers it 
necessary  to  (i)  strengthen  its  own  capacity  to  assess  the  impact  of  WTO  and  other  PTA 
obligations, tax reforms, subsidies, and various economic policies on budget revenues, industries, 
and the economy; and (ii) build a mechanism for tariff policy consultation to inform PTA and other 
trade negotiations in the short term, and trade policy formulation in the longer term. Long-term 
institutional  capacity  building  within  MOF  will  be  particularly  important  as  it  assumes  an 
increasingly active role in setting a wide-range of policies. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA will support the Government by (i) providing timely policy analysis and advice on a 
broad range of tax policies, (ii) strengthening MOF’s capacity to assess and evaluate the impact of 
WTO commitments, other PTA commitments, and various economic policies on state budget 
revenues, industries, and the economy; and (iii) support MOF to build a mechanism for trade policy 
consultation  to  inform  PTA  and  other  trade  negotiations  in  the  short  term,  and  tariff  policy 
formulation in the longer term; and (iv) assess the impact of phasing out subsidies. 
 
9.  The impact of the TA will be enhanced tax revenue collections. The outcome of the TA will 
be improved tax and trade policy formulation processes.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The key TA activities are divided into four components:  
(i)  Component  1:  Tax  revenue  enhancement.  This  component  will  support  the 
Department of Tax Policy at MOF to improve domestic tax policies that enhance 
both  revenue  and  economic  growth.  This  will  be  done  by  working  with  the 
Department of Tax Policy to provide: 
(a)  Technical papers on tax issues identified by the Department of Tax Policy. 
(b)  Workshops (public consultations) on selected tax policies.

4   
(ii)  Component 2: Strengthening capacity to carry out economic policy analysis. 
This component will support MOF’s ongoing efforts to strengthen its capacity and 
analytical tools for assessing and evaluating the impact of WTO and other PTA 
commitments, as well as the impact of other economic policies on budget revenues 
and the economy as a whole. This will be done by working with the Department for 
International Cooperation (DIC) at MOF to: 
(a)  Update  computable  general  equilibrium  models  to  assess  economy-wide 
effects  of  policy  changes  and  construct  a  revenue  forecasting  model  to 
assess the impact of WTO commitments and other PTA commitments on tax 
revenues  over  the  medium  term;  and  update  other  statistical  tools  for 
assessing trade policy effects (continuing development of the "effective rates 
of protection" model,4 for example). 
(b)  Provide in-house training and workshops for technical staff from MOF and 
other relevant agencies in trade policy analysis, trade policy tools, statistical 
packages, and other issues identified by the Policy Advisory Group. 
(c)  Carry out an annual macroeconomic outlook report.  
(iii)  Component 3: Mechanism for trade policy formulation and negotiations. This 
component will support MOF and relevant line ministries to build a mechanism for 
trade policy consultation to inform PTAs and other trade negotiations in the short 
term,  and  tariff  policy  formulation  in  the  longer  term.  This  component  will  be 
integrated with component 2 to ensure maximum synergy. This will be done by 
working with the Department for International Cooperation (DIC) to: 
(a)  Explore  options  to  improve  the  institutional  process  for  tariff  policy 
consultation  for  informing  PTAs,  drawing  on  best  international  practices 
adjusted to the Viet Nam environment. 
(b)  Utilize outputs under Component 2 [economy-wide approach].  
(c)  Strengthen DIC capacity and staff skills for trade negotiations.5 
(d)  Carry  out  economic  and  trade  assessment  of  selected  major  industries 
identified by DIC. 
(iv)  Component 4: Assessing subsidies. This component will support DIC to:  
(a)  assess the impact on the economy of phasing out current subsidies under 
WTO commitments, and  
(b)  analyze  the  economic  effects  of  remaining  subsidies  (mainly  investment 
incentives and other incentives such as land-use fees). Consideration will be 
given  to  identifying  market-efficient  instruments  to  enhance  the 
competitiveness  of  the  economy  and  mitigate  any  negative  effects  from 
phasing out subsidies. 
 
11.  This  TA  project  complements  the  activities  of  ADB  and  other  development  partners, 
including Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), the European Commission, 
United  Kingdom  Department  for  International  Development  (DFID),  United  States  Agency  for 
International Development (USAID), and the World Bank. AusAID and DFID has established the 
“Beyond WTO” trust fund to support the Office of Government coordinate implementation of Viet 
Nam’s  WTO  commitments.  USAID  is  supporting  the  Government’s  WTO  legislative  agenda 
through the STARS project. The European Commission is supporting the Government’s trade 
policy agenda through the MUTRAP project, with a focus on product standards and fiscal policy 
through its Fiscal Policy and Legal Advisory Services Project. The World Bank is supporting the 
“Beyond  WTO”  trust  fund  with  TA,  and  is  supporting  customs  reforms  through  its  Customs

Modernization  Project  and  Tax  Administration  Modernization  project,  which  focuses  on 
computerizing  systems  in  the  central  tax  office  and  regional  tax  offices.  Both  the  European 
Commission and the World Bank projects target modernization of customs and tax administration 
offices, within the framework of MOF’s public financial management reform efforts. ADB  has 
worked closely with other development partners in preparing this TA project, and will continue to do 
so during implementation to ensure efficient use of resources. The Japan Fund for Public Policy 
Training also provides capacity building activities to the MOF. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $360,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will provide in-kind contribution equivalent to 
$60,000 through the provision of counterpart staff, office space and utilities, administrative services, 
and physical facilities. Appendix 2 gives the details of cost estimates and the financing plan.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Ministry of Finance will be the Executing Agency. MOF has been selected as the 
Executing Agency based on its revenue mandate and its lead role in trade negotiations along with 
the Ministry of Industry and Trade. Within MOF, the DIC will be responsible for implementing 
activities under the TA project, as it is responsible for coordinating and implementing MOF’s “After 
WTO Action Plan”. The TA project will be implemented over 18 months, starting February 2008 to 
July 2009. To facilitate advance disbursements for workshops, publications, and statistical software 
under the three components will require the Advance Payment Facility (APF).  
 
14.  A team of international consultants will be paired with national consultants to implement the 
TA activities. International and national consultants will be recruited by ADB on an individual basis 
to implement activities. Consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). A total of 20 (7 international and 13 
national)  persons-months  will  be  required.  Five  international  consultants  and  five  national 
consultants will be engaged to carry out the activities. The consultants’ terms of reference are in 
Appendix 3. Procurement of equipment will be undertaken by consultants in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Various workshops and in-
house training programs will be held to encourage participatory discussions on tax issues and 
subsidies and increase capacity of government staff and researchers. The ADB project team will 
lead the team of consultants. 
 
15.  The consultants will be responsible for providing reports and deliverables as required under 
their terms of references. The timing of each TA activity will be determined in consultation with 
MOF.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Viet Nam for the After WTO Support—Capacity Building for Tax and Trade Policy 
Analysis, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
I.   Component 1: Tax Revenue Enhancement 
 
A.   Tax Policy Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
1.  This component will engage an international consultant paired with national consultants 
to  assist  the  Department  of  Tax  Policy  in  assessing  selected  tax  issues  identified  by  the 
Department of Tax Policy. The consultant will make recommendations on ways to improve 
selected tax policies with a view toward enhancing revenue in the medium term. 
 
2.  The international consultant will be a specialist in the area of tax policy. The international 
consultant will report directly to the Department of Tax Policy and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) officer responsible. The consultant’s main tasks will be to: 
 
(i)  carry out technical studies on selected tax issues as identified by the Department 
of Tax Policy, and 
(ii)  develop a module on tax policy analysis and provide training for staff at the 
Department of Tax Policy. 
 
 3.  Deliverables. The international consultant will submit technical papers on selected tax 
issues and provide training materials on tax policy analysis. 
 
B.   Tax Policy Analysts (2 national, 4 person-months) 
 
4.  This component will engage two national consultants (total of 4 persons-months) to 
assist  the  Department  of  Tax  Policy  with  assessing  selected  tax  issues  identified  by  the 
Department of Tax Policy. The consultants will make recommendations on ways to improve the 
selected tax policy with a view toward enhancing revenue in the medium term. 
 
5.  The national consultants will have similar experience to the international consultant, 
applied to Viet Nam. The national consultants must have at least 5 years of experience working 
on these issues. The national consultants will: 
 
(i)  assist the international consultant, and  
(ii)  carry  out  other  technical  studies  on  selected  tax  issues  identified  by  the 
Department of Tax Policy. 
 
 6.  Deliverables. The national consultants will submit technical papers on selected tax 
issues. 
  
II.   Component 2: Strengthening Capacity to Carry Out Economic Policy Analysis 
 
A.  Economic Modeling Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
7.  This activity will engage one international consultant paired with one national consultant 
to work with the Policy Advisory Group to provide capacity building support to the Ministry of 
Finance  (MOF).  Support  will  include  upgrading  computable  general  equilibrium  modeling 
capacity, training in trade policy analysis, and carrying out an in-house economic outlook report. 
The international consultant will provide 1 person-month equivalent of training.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
8.  The international consultant will be a specialist in computable general equilibrium (CGE) 
modeling and will have some experience in tax and trade policy analysis. The international 
consultant  will  report  directly  to  MOF  and  the  ADB  officer  responsible.  In  particular  the 
consultant will:  
 
(i)  provide support to MOF to update the CGE model and provide training in its 
operations,  
(ii)  upgrade MOF’s revenue forecasting model,  
(iii)  work with the national consultant to update the effective rates of protection model, 
and 
(iv)  work with the national consultant to develop a training module on tailor-made 
economic models. 
 
9.  Deliverables.  The  international  consultant,  working  with  the  national  consultant,  is 
expected to submit a series of technical reports on the CGE model, revenue forecasting model, 
and  effective  rates  of  protection.  The  consultants  will  produce  training  materials  on  the 
economic models.  
 
B.  Macroeconomist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
10.  This  component  will  engage  one  international  consultant  to  assist  MOF  staff  with 
developing an economic outlook report that will include medium-term forecasts. The issues and 
topics included in the outlook report will be identified by MOF. The international consultant will 
work with the national CGE specialist to formulate forecasts and the macroeconomic framework, 
and construct the required database. The consultant will report directly to MOF and the ADB 
officer responsible.  
 
11.  The international consultant will be a specialist in macroeconomic policy, with relevant 
experience in developing countries. Knowledge of and experience in Viet Nam would be an 
advantage. In particular the consultant will: 
 
(i)  assist MOF staff with constructing the database for carrying out an economic 
outlook report, 
(ii)  help develop the macroeconomic framework, and 
(iii)  prepare the economic outlook. 
  
12.  Deliverables. The macroeconomist will submit the database, the first macroeconomic 
outlook report produced by MOF including medium-term projections, a template and manual for 
MOF staff to produce the second economic outlook.  
 
C.  Economic Modeling Specialist (5 person-months) 
 
13.  This activity will engage a national consultant to work with the Policy Advisory Group to 
provide capacity building support to MOF though upgrading CGE modeling capacity and training 
in trade policy analysis; and produce the macroeconomic outlook report. The national consultant 
will provide 5 persons-months of consulting and training services.   
 
14.  The  national  consultant  will  have  similar  experience  to  the  international  consultant, 
applied to Viet Nam. The national consultant must be familiar with CGE modeling and trade 
policy and have at least 5 years of experience working on these issues. The national consultant 
will:

(iv)  support the international consultant to develop a training module and provide 
training; and 
(v)  sketch out a work plan with MOF for providing policy analysis and training to 
MOF staff.  
 
15.  Deliverables. The national consultant is expected to submit a series of technical reports 
on tax and trade policy analysis using the CGE model and revenue forecasting model, and  
effective rates of protection model. 
 
III.  Component 3: Improved Mechanism for Trade Policy Formulation 
 
A.  Trade and Institution Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
16.  This component will engage one international consultant (1 person-month) paired with 
one national consultant to support MOF and relevant line ministries to build a mechanism for 
trade policy consultation to inform preferential trade arrangements (PTAs) negotiations in the 
short term, and tariff policy formulation in the longer term. The international consultant should 
have extensive knowledge of international trade policy and tariff setting mechanisms in other 
countries and be familiar with the policy making process in Viet Nam. The national consultants 
should be trade economists. The international consultant will: 
 
(i)  explore  options  to  improve  the  mechanism  for  trade  policy  consultation  for 
facilitating  PTAs;  the  mechanism  should  take  an  economy-wide  approach, 
drawing on best international practices adjusted to the Viet Nam environment; 
(ii)  work with ADB staff to develop training modules for trade negotiations, and 
manage logistics for a workshop on trade negotiations. 
 
17.  Deliverables. The consultant will submit a technical report on options for improving the 
mechanism for trade policy consultation and materials for a workshop on trade negotiations. 
 
B.  Trade Policy Specialist (national, 3 person-months) 
 
18.  This component will engage one national consultant (total 3 person-months) to support 
MOF and relevant line ministries to build a mechanism for trade policy consultation to inform 
PTAs negotiations in the short term, and tariff policy formulation in the longer term. The national 
consultant should be a trade economist. The task of the national consultant will be to carry out 
selected industry case studies as inputs into the trade policy making exercise. The case studies 
will be identified by the Department of International Cooperation (DIC).  
 
19.  Deliverable. The consultant will submit industry case studies.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
IV.  Component 4: Subsidies 
 
A.  Fiscal Policy Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
20.  This component will engage one international consultant (1 person-month) paired with 
one national consultant (1 person-month) to support MOF to assess the impact of remaining 
subsidies on investment, trade, and the budget, including those subsidies that will be phased 
out  over  the  next  5  years  under  WTO  commitments.  These  subsidies  include  investment 
incentives and land-use fees. The international consultant will work with the national consultant 
specializing in CGE modeling in carrying out this exercise. The international consultant should 
have experience in assessing the impact of subsidies and taxes on the economy, knowledge of 
WTO  rules,  and  knowledge  of  Viet  Nam's  trade  policy  and  economy.  The  international 
consultant will report to DIC and the ADB officer responsible. The international consultant will: 
 
(i)  assess the impact of subsidies that will be phased out over the next 5 years on 
the economy; 
(ii)  assess  the  impact  of  remaining  subsidies  (mainly  investment  incentives  and 
land-use fees) on budget revenues, investment, trade, and equity. 
(iii)  identify  market-friendly  instruments  that  promote  competitiveness  and 
investment, and identify mitigating policies to address impact of a phase out of 
subsidies on the community. 
 
21.  Deliverables. The consultant will submit technical report on impact of subsidies on the 
economy.  
 
B.  Fiscal Policy Analyst (National, 1 person-month) 
 
22.  This component will engage one national consultant (1 person-month) to support the 
international fiscal policy specialist consultant (para. 20) and MOF. The national consultant 
should have experience in fiscal policy and possess skills in statistical analysis. The national 
consultant will report to DIC and the ADB officer responsible. The task of the national consultant 
will be to assist the international consultant with activities i to iii of para. 20 above and construct 
the database on subsidies and supporting regulations and policy instructions.  
 
23.  Deliverables.  The  consultant  will  submit  the  database  on  subsidies  and  report 
synthesizing policies and regulations on subsidies.
